topic: 9. Tyzzers Disease_ Maravillas, Chester Kent Y.

questions.stem: Tyzzer’s disease in foals is BEST described as:

options.label: A
options.text: A chronic cholangitis of adult horses

options.label: B
options.text: An acute, rapidly progressive bacterial hepatitis in foals 7–42 days old

options.label: D
options.text: A parasitic enteritis of adult horses

questions.explanation: Tyzzer’s disease is an acute, rapidly progressive bacterial hepatitis in very young foals, often fatal. It is not chronic adult cholangitis (A), viral encephalitis (C), or parasitic enteritis (D).

questions.stem: The etiologic agent of Tyzzer’s disease is:
questions.explanation: The causative agent is *Clostridium piliforme* (formerly *Bacillus piliformis*). *C. tetani* (A), *Salmonella* (C), and *Rhodococcus* (D) cause different diseases.

questions.stem: Clostridium piliforme is BEST characterized as:

options.label: B
options.text: A spore-forming, gram-negative, obligate anaerobic, intracellular filamentous rod

questions.explanation: *C. piliforme* is a spore-forming, gram-negative, obligate anaerobic, intracellular, filamentous rod. The other descriptions (A, C, D) fit different organisms.

questions.stem: How are foals most commonly infected with C. piliforme?

options.label: C
options.text: Fecal-oral ingestion of contaminated soil or feces

questions.explanation: Foals are infected via the fecal-oral route by ingesting contaminated soil or feces from adult horses or the environment. Transplacental (A), inhalation (B), and tick-borne routes (D) are not typical.

questions.stem: The typical age range for foals affected by Tyzzer’s disease is:

options.label: B
options.text: 7–42 days, with an average around 20 days

questions.explanation: The classic age range is 7–42 days with an average around 20 days, reflecting susceptibility of very young foals. Neonates (A), older foals (C), and adults (D) are not the usual patients.

questions.stem: Which clinical signs are commonly associated with Tyzzer’s disease in foals?

options.label: B
options.text: Loss of suckle reflex, depression progressing to recumbency, fever, tachypnea, tachycardia, icterus, diarrhea, dehydration, shock, seizures, coma, or sudden death

options.label: C
options.text: Chronic weight loss and intermittent colic

questions.explanation: Clinical signs include loss of suckle, depression to recumbency, fever, tachypnea, tachycardia, icterus, petechiation, diarrhea, dehydration, shock, seizures, coma, or sudden death. Respiratory-only (A), chronic colic (C), or laminitis (D) do not characterize this disease.

questions.stem: Which organs are MAINLY affected pathologically in Tyzzer’s disease?

options.label: B
options.text: Liver (acute multifocal hepatitis), myocardium (myocarditis), and intestines (enteritis)

questions.explanation: Pathology mainly involves acute multifocal hepatitis, myocarditis, and enteritis. Kidney/spleen (A), CNS (C), or hoof/skin (D) are not the primary targets described.

questions.stem: Gross hepatic lesions in Tyzzer’s disease typically show:

options.label: B
options.text: Swollen liver with 1–5 mm white foci scattered throughout the parenchyma and icteric tissues with petechial hemorrhages

options.label: D
options.text: Diffuse black discoloration of the liver

questions.explanation: Grossly, the liver is swollen with 1–5 mm white foci scattered through the parenchyma, and tissues are icteric with petechial hemorrhages. Fibrous nodules (A), gallstones (C), or black liver (D) are not typical.

questions.stem: Additional pathologic findings that may be present in Tyzzer’s disease include:

options.label: A
options.text: Enterocolitis, myositis, pleural effusion, pulmonary congestion and edema, and lymphoid necrosis or depletion

options.label: B
options.text: Purely neurologic lesions without systemic involvement

questions.explanation: Additional findings may include enterocolitis, myositis, pleural effusion, pulmonary congestion and edema, and lymphoid necrosis or depletion, reflecting multisystem involvement. Purely neurologic (B), renal-only (C), or gastric-only (D) lesions are not typical.

questions.stem: Which histologic feature confirms Tyzzer’s disease?

options.label: B
options.text: Intracellular interlacing bundles of filamentous bacilli (C. piliforme) at lesion peripheries on silver stains (e.g., Warthin-Starry, Dieterle)

questions.explanation: Histologic confirmation shows intracellular interlacing bundles of filamentous bacilli at lesion peripheries, highlighted by silver stains such as Warthin-Starry or Dieterle. Viral inclusions (A), fungal hyphae (C), or protozoal cysts (D) indicate other pathogens.

questions.stem: On CBC in foals with Tyzzer’s disease, which pattern is commonly seen?

options.label: B
options.text: Hemoconcentration and hyperfibrinogenemia with normal-to-low leukocyte counts

questions.explanation: CBC commonly shows hemoconcentration and hyperfibrinogenemia with normal-to-low leukocyte counts, consistent with severe systemic disease and dehydration. The other patterns (A, C, D) do not match the description.

questions.stem: Which biochemistry findings are typical of Tyzzer’s disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Hypoglycemia, metabolic acidosis, and marked elevations in liver enzymes (SDH, GGT, ALP, bilirubin)

options.label: D
options.text: Normal lab values in all foals

questions.explanation: Typical biochemical changes include hypoglycemia, metabolic acidosis, and marked elevations in liver enzymes (SDH, GGT, ALP, bilirubin). Hyperglycemia with normal liver values (B) or isolated hypocalcemia (C) are not characteristic.

questions.stem: What is the primary route of transmission for C. piliforme in horse populations?
questions.explanation: Transmission is primarily fecal-oral from contaminated environmental sources. Milk (A), sexual (C), and insect-borne (D) routes are not major pathways.

questions.stem: Which antimicrobial regimens are listed as drugs of choice for Tyzzer’s disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Penicillin, tetracycline, erythromycin, sulfamethoxazole–trimethoprim, and metronidazole

questions.explanation: Recommended antimicrobials include penicillin, tetracycline, erythromycin, sulfamethoxazole–trimethoprim, and metronidazole targeting Gram-negative anaerobic bacteria. Macrolides alone (B), cephalosporins only (C), or antifungals (D) are incomplete or inappropriate.

questions.stem: Which drugs may be used for seizure management in affected foals?
questions.explanation: Diazepam and midazolam are used to control seizures in affected foals. Phenylbutazone (B) and flunixin (C) are NSAIDs; omeprazole (D) is for gastric ulcers.

questions.stem: Which additional drug is used to help reduce intestinal ammonia production in these foals?
questions.explanation: Lactulose helps reduce intestinal ammonia production and absorption, mitigating hepatic encephalopathy. Sucralfate (A), furosemide (C), and lidocaine (D) have other indications.

questions.stem: Why should barbiturates be used with caution for seizure management in Tyzzer’s disease?

options.label: A
options.text: They have no effect on seizures

options.label: B
options.text: They may worsen hepatic encephalopathy and depress CNS function in foals with severe liver disease

questions.explanation: Barbiturates can worsen CNS depression and hepatic encephalopathy in foals with severe liver disease, so they must be used with great caution. They do treat seizures (A), but risk outweighs benefit in many cases; they do not universally cause laminitis (C) or inactivate antibiotics (D).

questions.stem: Which conditions are important DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSES for Tyzzer’s disease in foals?

options.label: A
options.text: Neonatal septicemia, neonatal isoerythrolysis, viral hepatitis, and toxic hepatopathy

options.label: D
options.text: Colic due to ascarid impaction only

questions.explanation: Important differentials include neonatal septicemia, neonatal isoerythrolysis, viral hepatitis, and toxic hepatopathies, which can also cause acute hepatic dysfunction and systemic illness. The other sets (B–D) are unrelated.

questions.stem: What is the overall prognosis for foals diagnosed with Tyzzer’s disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Excellent, with most surviving with minimal therapy

options.label: B
options.text: Grave; most foals die within 24 hours of onset of clinical signs

options.label: C
options.text: Good, provided antibiotics are given once daily

options.label: D
options.text: Fair, with most foals recovering spontaneously

questions.explanation: Prognosis is grave; most foals die within 24 hours of clinical onset despite therapy. It is not generally excellent (A), nor usually good with minimal treatment (C), and spontaneous recovery (D) is rare.

questions.stem: Which management strategy could help reduce Tyzzer’s disease risk in a breeding facility?

options.label: A
options.text: Allowing fecal accumulation in foaling stalls

options.label: B
options.text: Maintaining good hygiene to reduce environmental contamination with adult horse feces

options.label: D
options.text: Increasing stocking density of mares and foals

questions.explanation: Reducing environmental contamination (e.g., good hygiene, limiting access to feces in foaling areas) may help lower infection risk. Fecal accumulation (A), cutting vaccines (C), and crowding (D) increase disease and transmission risks.
